title: Build Tailscale ACL Policy Generator and Validator
description:
Tailscale ACL Policy Generator

PRIORITY: P2 (Medium)
STATUS: Planned
EPIC: TailOpsMCP-dv2 (Security Integrations)

PURPOSE:
Auto-generate Tailscale ACL policies from targets.yaml configuration to enforce least-privilege network access between managed targets.

TAILSCALE API RESEARCH:
- No official Python SDK - use requests library directly
- REST API endpoint: https://api.tailscale.com/api/v2/tailnet/{tailnet}/acl
- Authentication: Bearer token or Basic auth with API key
- GET /tailnet/{tailnet}/acl - retrieve current ACL policy (JSON)
- POST /tailnet/{tailnet}/acl - update ACL policy (JSON body)
- If-Match header for optimistic concurrency control
- Test endpoint: POST /tailnet/{tailnet}/acl/validate

ACL POLICY STRUCTURE:
{
  "acls": [
    {"action": "accept", "src": ["group:admins"], "dst": ["*:*"]},
    {"action": "accept", "src": ["tag:web"], "dst": ["tag:db:3306"]}
  ],
  "tagOwners": {"tag:web": ["autogroup:admin"]},
  "groups": {"group:admins": ["user@example.com"]}
}

ARCHITECTURE:
1. ACLGenerator reads targets.yaml and extracts metadata.tags
2. Maps tags to Tailscale tag-based access rules
3. Generates ACL JSON with default-deny + explicit allows
4. TailscaleClient wraps API calls with auth header
5. Validation mode tests policy before deployment
6. MCP tool provides generate/validate/deploy operations

GENERATED PATTERNS:
- Default deny all traffic
- Tag-based service segmentation (tag:web, tag:db, tag:monitoring)
- Port-specific access rules from capabilities (container:read -> 2375, ssh -> 22)
- Group-based admin access (group:admins -> all targets)
- Auto-generate from targets.yaml tags field

IMPLEMENTATION STEPS:
1. Create src/integrations/tailscale_client.py (requests wrapper)
2. Create src/generators/acl_generator.py (policy builder)
3. Add MCP tools:
   - generate_tailscale_acl() -> JSON policy
   - validate_tailscale_acl(policy_json) -> validation result
   - deploy_tailscale_acl(policy_json, dry_run=True) -> deployment result
4. Add tests with mock Tailscale API responses
5. Document in HOMELAB_FEATURES.md usage examples

DEPENDENCIES:
- requests library (already in requirements.txt)
- TargetRegistry (existing)
- Environment variable: TAILSCALE_API_KEY

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Generate ACL policy from targets.yaml tags
- Validate policy via Tailscale API before deployment
- Dry-run mode to preview changes
- Audit log of ACL deployments
- Handle API errors gracefully

REFERENCES:
- Tailscale ACL Docs: https://tailscale.com/kb/1018/acls
- API Reference: https://tailscale.com/api#tag/acl

title: Add SIEM Log Forwarding Integration
description:
SIEM Log Forwarding Integration

PRIORITY: P2 (Medium)
STATUS: Planned
EPIC: TailOpsMCP-dv2 (Security Integrations)

PURPOSE:
Forward TailOpsMCP audit logs and on-demand target logs to external SIEM systems (Loki, Elasticsearch, Wazuh) for centralized security monitoring and correlation.

LIBRARY RESEARCH:

LOKI INTEGRATION:
- No official Python client library
- Option 1: loki-logger-handler (logging handler, push logs to Loki HTTP API)
- Option 2: Direct HTTP POST to /loki/api/v1/push
- Format: JSON with streams array and label sets
- Example: {"streams": [{"stream": {"job": "tailopsmcp", "level": "info"}, "values": [["timestamp_ns", "log line"]]}]}

ELASTICSEARCH INTEGRATION:
- Library: elasticsearch-py (official client)
- Bulk API for batching: helpers.bulk(es_client, actions)
- ECS format support (Elastic Common Schema)
- Index pattern: tailopsmcp-logs-YYYY.MM.DD
- Mapping templates for structured audit logs

WAZUH INTEGRATION:
- Uses OSSEC protocol (syslog or JSON over TCP/UDP)
- Library: socket or logging.handlers.SysLogHandler
- Format: JSON with required fields (timestamp, hostname, agent)

ARCHITECTURE:
1. SIEMForwarder abstraction with backend plugins
2. Gateway-side: Forward own audit logs (AuditLogger integration)
3. On-demand: Query target logs via execute_command and forward
4. Batching: Collect logs in buffer, flush every N seconds or M bytes
5. Retry logic: Exponential backoff with circuit breaker
6. Metadata enrichment: Add target_id, tags, environment labels

LOG SOURCES:
- TailOpsMCP audit logs (tool invocations, policy decisions)
- SecurityMonitor alerts (runtime security, compliance violations)
- Target system logs (queried via journalctl, docker logs)
- SSH session logs (command execution audit trail)

IMPLEMENTATION STEPS:
1. Create src/integrations/siem/forwarder.py (abstraction layer)
2. Create src/integrations/siem/loki_backend.py (HTTP API client)
3. Create src/integrations/siem/elasticsearch_backend.py (elasticsearch-py wrapper)
4. Create src/integrations/siem/wazuh_backend.py (syslog handler)
5. Integrate with AuditLogger to auto-forward audit events
6. Add MCP tools:
   - configure_siem_forwarding(backend, destination, config)
   - query_target_logs(target_id, service, timerange) -> forward to SIEM
   - test_siem_connection(backend) -> health check
7. Add batching and retry logic with asyncio
8. Document configuration in HOMELAB_FEATURES.md

CONFIGURATION EXAMPLE:
SIEM_BACKEND=loki
SIEM_LOKI_URL=http://loki:3100
SIEM_BATCH_SIZE=100
SIEM_FLUSH_INTERVAL=10

DEPENDENCIES:

- requests (already available)
- AuditLogger (existing)
- TargetRegistry (existing)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Forward audit logs to Loki/Elasticsearch/Wazuh
- Query and forward target logs on-demand
- Batch logs with configurable flush interval
- Retry failed deliveries with exponential backoff
- Enrich logs with target metadata and tags
- Support multiple SIEM backends simultaneously

title: Deploy Production Ready Monitoring
description:
Deploy Production Ready Monitoring Stack

PRIORITY: P2
STATUS: Planned
EPIC: TailOpsMCP-erq (Sprint Phase 3)

PURPOSE:
Deploy a complete, production-ready monitoring stack (Prometheus, Grafana, Loki, Alertmanager) to provide comprehensive observability for TailOpsMCP and managed targets in homelab environments.

STACK COMPONENTS:

1. PROMETHEUS (Metrics Collection):
   - Time-series database for metrics
   - Scrapes /metrics endpoint from TailOpsMCP (TailOpsMCP-nsk)
   - Scrapes Node Exporter for host metrics
   - Scrapes cAdvisor for container metrics
   - Default retention: 15 days (configurable)

2. GRAFANA (Visualization):
   - Web UI for dashboards and alerts
   - Pre-configured dashboards from TailOpsMCP-nsk
   - Data sources: Prometheus, Loki
   - Authentication: anonymous read-only or OAuth via Tailscale

3. LOKI (Log Aggregation):
   - Log storage and querying
   - Receives logs from SIEM forwarder (TailOpsMCP-eie)
   - Retention: 7 days (configurable)
   - Index on labels only (cost-effective)

4. ALERTMANAGER (Alert Routing):
   - Receives alerts from Prometheus rules
   - Routes to notification system (TailOpsMCP-0o1)
   - Deduplication and grouping
   - Silencing and inhibition rules

5. NODE EXPORTER (Host Metrics):
   - CPU, memory, disk, network metrics
   - Deployed to gateway host
   - Optional: Deploy to managed targets via SSH

6. CADVISOR (Container Metrics):
   - Per-container resource usage
   - CPU, memory, network, filesystem
   - Auto-discovers Docker containers

DEPLOYMENT METHOD:
- Docker Compose stack (uses existing compose_manager.py)
- TailOpsMCP deploys its own monitoring using MCP tools
- Stack template: configs/monitoring-stack/docker-compose.yml
- Configuration templates in configs/monitoring-stack/

DOCKER COMPOSE STRUCTURE:
services:
  prometheus:
    image: prom/prometheus:latest
    volumes:
      - ./prometheus.yml:/etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml
      - prometheus-data:/prometheus
    ports:
      - 9090:9090
  
  grafana:
    image: grafana/grafana:latest
    volumes:
      - ./grafana/provisioning:/etc/grafana/provisioning
      - grafana-data:/var/lib/grafana
    ports:
      - 3000:3000
  
  loki:
    image: grafana/loki:latest
    volumes:
      - ./loki.yml:/etc/loki/loki.yml
      - loki-data:/loki
    ports:
      - 3100:3100
  
  alertmanager:
    image: prom/alertmanager:latest
    volumes:
      - ./alertmanager.yml:/etc/alertmanager/alertmanager.yml
    ports:
      - 9093:9093
  
  node-exporter:
    image: prom/node-exporter:latest
    ports:
      - 9100:9100
  
  cadvisor:
    image: gcr.io/cadvisor/cadvisor:latest
    volumes:
      - /:/rootfs:ro
      - /var/run:/var/run:ro
      - /sys:/sys:ro
      - /var/lib/docker/:/var/lib/docker:ro
    ports:
      - 8080:8080

PROMETHEUS SCRAPE CONFIGURATION:
scrape_configs:
  - job_name: tailopsmcp
    static_configs:
      - targets: ['host.docker.internal:8000']
    scrape_interval: 15s
  
  - job_name: node-exporter
    static_configs:
      - targets: ['node-exporter:9100']
  
  - job_name: cadvisor
    static_configs:
      - targets: ['cadvisor:8080']

ALERTMANAGER INTEGRATION:
- Routes to notification channels configured in TailOpsMCP-0o1
- Webhook receiver: http://host.docker.internal:8000/webhooks/alertmanager
- Severity-based routing (critical -> SMS, high -> Slack, medium -> email)

3. TailOpsMCP Runtime Security (from TailOpsMCP-nsk)
4. Host Metrics (Node Exporter dashboard)

title: Add Runtime Security Monitoring Integration
description:
Deploy and manage Falco and auditd runtime security monitoring on targets via gateway orchestration.

TOOL RESEARCH:
- Falco: Cloud-native runtime security, gRPC output, eBPF/kernel module
- Auditd: Linux audit framework, syslog output, rule-based

ARCHITECTURE:
Gateway deploys Falco/auditd to targets → Collect events via gRPC/syslog → Parse into SecurityAlerts → Route to notifications

FALCO DEPLOYMENT:
Deploy as privileged Docker container on targets, custom rules in templates/falco-rules/, events via gRPC

FALCO RULES:
- Suspicious shell in container
- Privilege escalation
- Sensitive file access
- Container escape attempts
- Anomalous network connections

AUDITD DEPLOYMENT:
Deploy rules to /etc/audit/rules.d/, monitor SSH keys, privilege escalation, file changes, kernel modules

PYTHON INTEGRATION:
FalcoClient: gRPC streaming client
AuditdClient: SSH log tailing and parsing

EVENT CORRELATION:
Correlate Falco + auditd by timestamp/host/user, detect multi-stage attacks, map to MITRE ATT&CK

IMPLEMENTATION STEPS:
1. Create src/integrations/falco_client.py
2. Create src/integrations/auditd_client.py
3. Create src/integrations/runtime_monitor_manager.py
4. Add templates/falco-rules/ (custom rules)
5. Add templates/audit-rules/ (CIS-aligned)
6. Modify targets.yaml (runtime_monitoring config)
7. Integrate with SecurityMonitor

DEPLOYMENT WORKFLOW:
1. Validate target compatibility
2. SSH to target, install packages
3. Deploy rule files with templating
4. Start Falco container or auditd service
5. Verify event flow within 60s
6. Generate test event

MCP TOOLS:

- test_runtime_monitoring(target_id)
